subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. You know,
yesterday I released a very significant
video in my estimation. A monologue in
which I concluded that just by a single
thought we are able to create a shift in
our own consciousness. To me that is
a profound insight. When you consider
that we each, as individuals, have
somewhere between 50,000 and 70,000
thoughts a day, think of the
opportunities each thought represents
for a positive shift in our
consciousness. The obvious question
is: hasn't this been discovered before
and how come, if not, how come people
aren't all enlightened by now? I mean, the
human species has been on this planet
for tens of thousands of years, many tens
of thousands of years. By now we
should all be enlightened. And yet, we’re
not. Far, far from it, as a matter of fact.
So, is this talk about a shift in
consciousness based on a single thought,
is that just New Age - or some people
say newage - New Age BS? I think that's
funny because in general, I have to say,
when it comes to popular New Age culture
I’m more positively disposed, I suppose,
than many other people, including viewers.
But, nevertheless, I think there is a real
issue here and it reminded me of a time
when I was an undergraduate at the
University of Wisconsin. I graduated in
35 1969 and that was a very eventful year. I 19:09:30,000 36 00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:20,000 remember it well. In February of 1969
the black students on campus - there were
39 30,000 students on that campus, and 06:00:30,000 40 00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:29,000 although the black population is roughly
42 10% I think of our culture, there were 18:00:00,000 43 00:02:32,000 --> 00:02:35,000 roughly 500 black students enrolled, as I
remember out of 30,000 - they
were complaining about institutionalized
prejudice and discrimination. Believe
that! Well, they held a strike, a student
strike, they shut down the whole campus,
they literally did and I’m going to
talk about that. They held a
symposium. They brought in some of the
leading black speakers from around the
country to speak at the University of
Wisconsin as to why they were holding a
student strike. I attended all of those
talks. One of the speakers said
something that struck me as incredibly
profound and related to our topic.
He said, “The man doesn't move when he
sees the light. The man only moves when
he feels the heat.” Of course, the
student strike was an effort to put heat
on the man. As a matter of fact, it
worked. Within a year the Afro-American
Studies Department was formed at the
University of Wisconsin. I remember I had
a big argument with my father at the
time. He said to me, he said, “Well, why
should they have a Black Studies
Department? How come they
don't have a Jewish Studies Department?”
And I said to him, “Well, Dad, they actually
do. They have a Hebrew and Semitic
s Study Department.” I was studying
Biblical Hebrew at the university and
modern Hebrew as well. So, it's not as if
other cultures didn’t also have a
representation on campus. But the student
strike went even further because it was
the occasion - for me, I was a psychology
undergraduate
at the time - we formed a Psychology
Undergraduate Student Association. I
got up, I gave a little speech in front
of the group as it was forming. I
said, “I signed up as a psychology major
because I wanted to learn about myself.
But, what are we learning here? We’re
learning about rats running in mazes.
We're not really pursuing self-knowledge
at all.” I got elected as vice president
of the very first psychology student
association. We argued and achieved...
the university, the psychology department
institute new courses at our request.
For example, at that time in academic
Psychology, would you believe it, Sigmund
Freud, one of the most important figures
in human psychology in the 20th century
was not taught at Madison in the
Psychology Department. It certainly was
in the Psychiatry Department but
psychologists turned up their noses at
Freud, a big mistake in my opinion. So, we
got them to institute a course on Freud,
amongst other things. I took that
course, as a matter of fact. These
days, I think we can go a lot further
than just courses on Freud, but the point
is that sometimes we get really invested
emotionally in our ideas. When that
happens a simple thought isn't going to
necessarily be enough to change our
consciousness. We won't move just because
we see the light. We want to feel the
heat too, because we’re invested. We have an
emotional attachment to a particular
concept, a thought, an ideology, a way of
being. And you know, many of us, probably
most of us, are pretty comfortable with
who we are. We don't really want to
change. If things are going along well, if
we are enjoying some privileges, some
benefits, some comforts in our life, why
change? Certainly, it can be uncomfortable.
It can be embarrassing. It might uncover
things we have been hiding from
ourselves for a long time. But, here’s the
thing. Yes, you can shift your
consciousness with a single thought if
you’re relatively detached, if there
isn't a strong attachment. The examples
that I gave in yesterday’s monologue
were ones for which I didn’t have a
terribly strong attachment. So, I was able
to make a shift quickly and another
shift quickly based on a thought. And as
I said, when I sit down in preparation
for my interviews, well mostly monologues
because when I do interviews there's
someone in the room with me. When I do a
monologue I’m here by myself and I can
use that 15 seconds just to say to
myself, “OK, lets move up to a higher
level of consciousness now.” And it's
doable, just that easily. If you're not
able to do it just that easily
you need to ask yourself the right
questions. What's holding you back?
What are you attached to? Let me give
you this advice: as an empiricist, as
somebody who is, I would say, in the
scientific camp, primarily, but also very,
very open to the mystic, to the psychic,
to things that most scientists don't
want to acknowledge. How do you balance
those? How do you free
yourself from the prison of your own
attachments? Some of them you don't feel
are imprisoning you at all. Well, fine. But
the key is this: are there thoughts that
you are attached to, states of
consciousness that you are very, very
attached to, belief systems in particular
that you are very, very attached to for
which
you don't really have much in the way of
solid empirical evidence. For example, I
can tell you this: I watch television a
lot, I have for a long time. I watch the
news. I know, if you turn on one news
channel, the purpose of the channel it
seems to be is to get you outraged at a
particular political party. And there is
another channel and they seem to be
focused on getting you outraged at the
behavior of the other political party.
I think of the very first motion
picture ever released in the United
States. It was, The Birth of a
Nation. Once again, it was a piece of
media propaganda designed to engender
outrage. I’ve heard from a number of
viewers, I know there are things that
outrage you. I am inclined to think that
when we get outraged, when we get on our
high horse and say, “That is outrageous.
Something has to be done about that,” we
better be darned sure of our facts. If
you are outraged about anything, anything
at all, for which you don’t have solid
facts, maybe that's the sort of thing you
can begin to try to let go of. Outrage,
yes, outrage. And I’m saying this at a
time when I know outrage is high on all
sides. I don’t think it's necessarily the
healthiest of human emotions. Although a
lot of good can come out of it. Good came
out of it in 1969 in Madison, Wisconsin
when people got outraged. So, I’m not
against all outrage by any means. All I'm
suggesting is if you want to enter
higher states of consciousness you can
do that with a single thought. If you
find that that's not true for you, then
you have to ask yourself, what are you
attached to
that’s holding you back? Can you let
go of those attachments? Maybe one
way to help you let go of some of those
attachments is to ask yourself whether
they have a strong factual basis or not.
I’ll leave you with those thoughts, and
thank you for being with me.
[credits]
